title: Tidyverse
text:
#Sales Analysis, Tidyverse Challenge


1 Libraries
Load the following libraries.

library(tidyverse)

#> ── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
#> ✔ dplyr     1.1.2     ✔ readr     2.1.4
#> ✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.0
#> ✔ ggplot2   3.4.2     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
#> ✔ lubridate 1.9.2     ✔ tidyr     1.3.0
#> ✔ purrr     1.0.1     
#> ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
#> ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
#> ✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
#> ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(readxl)


2 Import Files

bikes_tbl <- read_excel(path = "./../../00_data/01_raw_data/bikes.xlsx")
orderlines_tbl <- read_excel("./../../00_data/01_raw_data/orderlines.xlsx")

#> New names:
#> • `` -> `...1`

bikeshops_tbl  <- read_excel("./../../00_data/01_raw_data/bikeshops.xlsx")

#joining data

bike_orderlines_joined_tbl <- orderlines_tbl %>%
  left_join(bikes_tbl, by = c("product.id" = "bike.id")) %>%
  left_join(bikeshops_tbl, by = c("customer.id" = "bikeshop.id"))

#wrangling data

bike_orderlines_wrangled_tbl <- bike_orderlines_joined_tbl %>% 
  separate(col = location, 
           into = c("City","State"),
           sep = ",") %>%
  mutate(total.price = price * quantity) %>%
  select(-...1,-gender) %>%
  select(-ends_with(".id")) %>%
  bind_cols(bike_orderlines_joined_tbl %>% select(order.id)) %>% 
  select(order.id, contains("order"), contains("model"), contains("category"),
         price, quantity, total.price,
         everything()) %>%
  rename(bikeshop = name) %>%
  set_names(names(.) %>% str_replace_all("\\.", "_"))


3 Manipulation of data (sales by state)

library(lubridate)

sales_by_state_tbl <- bike_orderlines_wrangled_tbl %>%
  select(State,total_price) %>%
  group_by(State) %>%
  summarize(sales = sum(total_price)) %>%
  mutate(sales_text = scales::dollar(sales, big.mark = ".", 
                                     decimal.mark = ",", 
                                     prefix = "", 
                                     suffix = " €"))
sales_by_state_tbl



  




4 Visualize sales by state data

sales_by_state_tbl %>% ggplot(aes(x = State, y =sales)) +
  geom_col(fill = "#2DC6D6") + 
  geom_label(aes(label = sales_text)) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1)) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::dollar_format(big.mark = ".", 
                                                    decimal.mark = ",", 
                                                    prefix = "", 
                                                    suffix = " €")) +
  labs(
    title    = "Revenue by State",
    subtitle = "State wise trend of sales",
    x = "", # Override defaults for x and y
    y = "Revenue"
  )

#> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'








#Manipulate sales by state and location data

sales_by_year_state_tbl <- bike_orderlines_wrangled_tbl %>%
  select(order_date,total_price,State) %>%
  mutate(year = year(order_date)) %>%
  group_by(year,State) %>%
  summarise(sales = sum(total_price)) %>% 
  ungroup() %>%
  mutate(sales_text = scales::dollar(sales, big.mark = ".", 
                                     decimal.mark = ",", 
                                     prefix = "", 
                                     suffix = " €"))

#> `summarise()` has grouped output by 'year'. You can override using the
#> `.groups` argument.

sales_by_year_state_tbl



  




5 Visualize sales by state data

sales_by_year_state_tbl %>% ggplot(aes(x = year, y = sales, fill = State)) + 
  geom_col() +
  facet_wrap(~ State) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::dollar_format(big.mark = ".", 
                                                    decimal.mark = ",", 
                                                    prefix = "", 
                                                    suffix = " €"))+
  labs(
    title = "Revenue by year and state",
    subtitle = "Each state different sales trend",
    fill = "State" 
  )

title: Data Acquisition
text:
#Challenge 1 #get top 10 rated movies from imdb

library(tidyverse)
library(httr)
library(rvest)

#> 
#> Attaching package: 'rvest'


#> The following object is masked from 'package:readr':
#> 
#>     guess_encoding


#import files

url  <- "https://www.imdb.com/chart/top/"
resp <- GET( url = "https://www.imdb.com/chart/top/",  
            add_headers('Accept-Language' = "en-US, en;q=0.5"))
imdb_html <- content(resp)

#Get movie titles

title_tbl <- read_html(url) %>% 
html_nodes(css=".titleColumn > a") %>%
html_text() %>%
head(10)


rank_tbl <- read_html(url) %>%
html_nodes(css=".titleColumn") %>%
html_text() %>%
head(10) %>%
stringr::str_extract("(?<= )[0-9]*(?=\\.\\n)")%>% 
as.numeric()


top10_movies <- tibble(rank = rank_tbl,title = title_tbl)


top10_movies



  



#Challenge 2
#Load Libraries —

library(tidyverse)
library(rvest)
library(glue)
library(xml2)


home_url <- "https://www.rosebikes.com"
home_html <- read_html("https://www.rosebikes.com/bikes/")


bike_family_tbl <- home_html %>%
  html_nodes(css = ".catalog-navigation__link") %>%
  html_attr("href") %>%
  str_replace_all("^/", "https://www.rosebikes.com/") %>%
  as_tibble() %>%
  rename("mtburl" = value)

#moutain bikes table

mtb_url <- read_html(bike_family_tbl$mtburl[1]) %>%
  html_nodes(css = ".catalog-category-bikes__picture-wrapper--left") %>%
  html_attr("href") %>%
  {glue("https://www.rosebikes.com{.}")} %>%
  as_tibble() %>%
  rename(URL = value)

#Names of count solo mtb tyes

name_tbl <- read_html(mtb_url$URL[1]) %>%
  html_nodes(css = ".basic-headline.basic-headline--no-margin.basic-headline--small.basic-headline--left .basic-headline__title") %>%
  html_text() 

#Price of count solo bike type

price_tbl <- read_html(mtb_url$URL[1]) %>%
html_nodes(css = ".product-tile-price__current.catalog-category-model__price-current .product-tile-price__current-value.catalog-category-model__price-current-value") %>%
html_text() %>%
gsub("[^0-9.-]","",.)

#Tibble Format

count_solo_tbl <- tibble(name = name_tbl, price = price_tbl)


count_solo_tbl

title: Data Wrangling
text:
library(tidyverse)

#> ── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
#> ✔ dplyr     1.1.2     ✔ readr     2.1.4
#> ✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.0
#> ✔ ggplot2   3.4.2     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
#> ✔ lubridate 1.9.2     ✔ tidyr     1.3.0
#> ✔ purrr     1.0.1     
#> ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
#> ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
#> ✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
#> ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(vroom)
library(data.table)

#> 
#> Attaching package: 'data.table'
#> 
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:lubridate':
#> 
#>     hour, isoweek, mday, minute, month, quarter, second, wday, week,
#>     yday, year
#> 
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:dplyr':
#> 
#>     between, first, last
#> 
#> The following object is masked from 'package:purrr':
#> 
#>     transpose


#Loading files

patent_url <- "./../../Patent_data_reduced/patent.tsv"
patent_dt <- fread(patent_url)
class(patent_dt)

#> [1] "data.table" "data.frame"

patent_assignee <- "./../../Patent_data_reduced/patent_assignee.tsv"
patent_assignee_dt <- fread(patent_assignee)
class(patent_assignee_dt)

#> [1] "data.table" "data.frame"

assignee_url <- "./../../Patent_data_reduced/assignee.tsv"
assignee_dt <- fread(assignee_url)
class(assignee_dt)

#> [1] "data.table" "data.frame"

uspc_url <- "./../../Patent_data_reduced/uspc.tsv"
uspc_dt <- fread(uspc_url)

#Challenge 1 List 10 us Companies with most patents

combined_data <- merge(patent_assignee_dt, assignee_dt, by.x="assignee_id", by.y ="id")
top10_us_company <- combined_data %>%
  filter(type == 2) %>%
  group_by(organization) %>%
  summarize(patent_count = n()) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  arrange(desc(patent_count))

#Challenge 2 - List top 10 companies with August 2014

aug_dt <- patent_dt[month(date) == 8 & year(date) == 2014]
  
combined_data <- merge(merge(aug_dt,patent_assignee_dt, by.x="id",by.y="patent_id"),assignee_dt, by.x="assignee_id",by.y="id")

top10_us_company <- combined_data %>%
  filter(type == 2) %>%
  group_by(organization) %>%
  summarize(patent_count = n()) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  arrange(desc(patent_count))

#Challenge3 - List top 5 most innovatiove companies

combined_data <- merge(patent_assignee_dt,assignee_dt,by.x="assignee_id",by.y="id")

company_patents <- combined_data %>%
filter(!(is.na(organization))) %>%
group_by(organization) %>%
summarize(patent_count = n()) %>%
ungroup() %>%
arrange(desc(patent_count)) %>% 
head(10)

top_10_companies <- head(company_patents, 10)$organization

filtered_data <- combined_data[organization %in% top_10_companies]

filtered_uspc <- merge(filtered_data, uspc_dt, by.x = "patent_id", by.y = "patent_id")

top_main_classes <- filtered_uspc %>%
  group_by(mainclass_id) %>%
  summarize(occurrences = n()) %>%
  arrange(desc(occurrences)) %>%
  head(5)

title: Data Visualization
text:
#Challenge 1 #Load Libraries

library(tidyverse)

#> ── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
#> ✔ dplyr     1.1.2     ✔ readr     2.1.4
#> ✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.0
#> ✔ ggplot2   3.4.2     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
#> ✔ lubridate 1.9.2     ✔ tidyr     1.3.0
#> ✔ purrr     1.0.1     
#> ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
#> ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
#> ✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
#> ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(lubridate)
library(ggthemes)


covid_data_tbl <- read_csv("https://covid.ourworldindata.org/data/owid-covid-data.csv") %>%
 filter(location %in% c("Germany","United States", "India","Spain")) %>%
 filter(!is.na(total_cases)) %>%
 filter(date < "2023-05-15") %>%
 ungroup()

#> Rows: 311581 Columns: 67
#> ── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
#> Delimiter: ","
#> chr   (4): iso_code, continent, location, tests_units
#> dbl  (62): total_cases, new_cases, new_cases_smoothed, total_deaths, new_dea...
#> date  (1): date
#> 
#> ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
#> ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


#plotting

covid_data_tbl %>% ggplot(aes(x=date, y = total_cases, color = location)) +
geom_line() +
  labs(
    title = "Global Total Cases over Time",
    subtitle = "Grouped by country",
    x = "Year",
    y = "Total Covid Cases"
  ) +
  theme_grey()







#Challenge 2

covid_mortality_tbl <- covid_data_tbl %>%
mutate(mortality_rate = total_deaths / population)

world <- map_data("world")


covid_mortality_tbl %>%
  filter(date == "2023-05-01") %>%
  ggplot(aes(mortality_rate)) +
  geom_map(aes(fill = mortality_rate, map_id = location), map = world) +
  expand_limits(x = world$long, y = world$lat) +
  coord_map("moll") +
  scale_fill_gradient2(low = "green", mid = "grey", high = "red", midpoint = 0.003) +
  labs(
    title = "Mortality Rate by Country",
    subtitle = "grouped by country",
    x = "",
    y = ""
  ) +
  theme_map()

title: Class Notes
text:
IMPORTANT: You can delete everything in here and start fresh. You might want to start by not deleting anything above this line until you know what that stuff is doing.
This is an .qmd file. It is plain text with special features. Any time you write just like this, it will be compiled to normal text in the website. If you put a # in front of your text, it will create a top level-header.

title: Links
text:
R is a free open-source programming language that can be used for statistical analysis, data-simulation, graphing, and lots of other stuff. Another free program is R-studio, that provides a nice graphic interface for R. Download R first, then download R-studio. Both can run on PCs, Macs or Linux. Students will be learning R in the stats labs using the lab manual .




Google is great, Google your problem
Stackoverflow is great, google will often take you there because someone has already asked your question, and someone else has answered, usually many people have answered your question many ways.
